intro: Cracca reptans, commonly known as creeping bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with slender, trailing stems that root at the nodes. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped blue or violet flowers from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and slightly hairy, often growing in opposite pairs along the stems. Cracca reptans thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges, meadows, and wetlands.
